Poisoning Prevention in Federated Learning and Differential Privacy via Stateful Proofs of Execution

Norrathep Rattanavipanon1 and Ivan De Oliveira Nunes2 
1Prince of Songkla University 2Rochester Institute of Technology
Abstract

The rise in IoT-driven distributed data analytics, coupled with increasing privacy concerns, has led to a demand for effective privacy-preserving and federated data collection/model training mechanisms. In response, approaches such as Federated Learning (FL) and Local Differential Privacy (LDP) have been proposed and attracted much attention over the past few years. However, they still share the common limitation of being vulnerable to poisoning attacks wherein adversaries compromising edge devices feed forged (a.k.a. “poisoned”) data to aggregation back-ends, undermining the integrity of FL/LDP results.

In this work, we propose a system-level approach to remedy this issue based on a novel security notion of Proofs of Stateful Execution (𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}) for IoT/embedded devices’ software. To realize the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} concept, we design 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}: a System-Level Approach for Poisoning Prevention. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} leverages commodity security features of embedded devices – in particular ARM TrustZone-M security extensions – to verifiably bind raw sensed data to their correct usage as part of FL/LDP edge device routines. As a consequence, it offers robust security guarantees against poisoning. Our evaluation, based on real-world prototypes featuring multiple cryptographic primitives and data collection schemes, showcases 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s security and low overhead.

I Introduction

With the rise of IoT and distributed big data analytics, data produced by edge devices have become increasingly important to understand users’ behaviors, enhance the user experience, and improve the quality of service. At the same time, privacy concerns have scaled significantly fueled by the collection (or leakage) of sensitive user data [24, 31, 58, 25, 28]. To reconcile privacy and utility, several mechanisms have been proposed to enable efficient and privacy-preserving collection of data produced by (typically resource-constrained) edge IoT devices. For example, Google has proposed Federated Learning (FL) aiming to collect and train models based on user data in a distributed, lightweight, and privacy-preserving fashion [30]; Microsoft is using Local Differential Privacy (LDP) to collect statistics of sensitive telemetry data [19].

As illustrated in Fig. 1, a crucial security obstacle in the adoption of these schemes is an adversary (𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}) that feeds back-end aggregators with forged data, sabotaging the entire collection process even when the other participants (other edge devices and the back-end) are honest. These attacks, known as poisoning attacks, have been widely recognized and are currently considered a major problem for both FL [53] and LDP [7]. Existing mitigations are either data-driven (e.g., in the case of data poisoning detection [57, 23, 6]) or algorithmic, e.g., by making FL and LDP mechanisms more resilient against these attacks [50, 32, 55, 33]. In both cases, security is by design best-effort, since these approaches cannot detect/prevent data poisoning at its source, i.e., at the edge devices themselves (typically, resource-constrained IoT devices).

In this work, we propose a systematic and practical treatment to address data poisoning at its source by leveraging architectural security features of contemporary embedded systems. This ensures that raw sensed data is correctly linked with its respective local processing, ultimately generating local aggregated data whose integrity and authenticity can be verified by back-ends in LDP/FL applications.

Specifically, we build upon the recently introduced concept of Proofs of Execution (PoX) [13] for simple embedded systems. 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} allows a low-end embedded device – Prover (𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}) – to convince a remote Verifier (𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}) that a specific function ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} has been executed successfully (i.e., from its first to its last instruction) on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Furthermore, PoX binds obtained results (or outputs) to a timely instance of this execution. A similar notion [34] has also been explored in high-end systems (e.g., general-purpose computers and servers, as opposed to embedded devices) based on trusted platform modules (TPMs) [54].

Intuitively, 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} can convey if the result received by an FL/LDP back-end (local aggregate data) truly originates from an edge device that has obtained this data through the correct execution of the expected software, thus thwarting poisoning attacks. On the other hand, as detailed next, the adoption of 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} in FL/LDP introduces unique non-trivial challenges that require re-thinking and re-designing existing PoX methods for this purpose.

I-A On the Insufficiency of Classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} to Avert Poisoning

As shown in Fig. 3, PoX is a challenge-response protocol composed of the following steps:

  1. 1.

    𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} sends an authenticated request containing a cryptographic challenge (𝒞​𝗁𝖺𝗅𝒞𝗁𝖺𝗅\sf{\mathcal{C}hal}) and asking 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} to execute ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}.

  2. 2.

    𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} authenticates the request, executes ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} obtaining output 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, and generates a cryptographic proof σ𝜎\sigma of this execution by measuring (signing or a MAC-ing) ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}’s implementation in program memory along with received 𝒞​𝗁𝖺𝗅𝒞𝗁𝖺𝗅\sf{\mathcal{C}hal}, produced 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, and execution metadata that conveys to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} if ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution was performed correctly.

  3. 3.

    𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} returns the output and proof (σ𝜎\sigma, 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}) to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

  4. 4.

    𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} verifies whether σ𝜎\sigma corresponds to the expected ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} code, received output 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, and expected execution metadata. If so, it concludes that ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} has executed successfully on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} with result 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}.

Step 2 above must be securely implemented by a root of trust (RoT) within 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} to ensure (1) temporal consistency between ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}’s measurement and its execution, (2) correctness of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution and generated 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} at run-time, and (3) confidentiality of the cryptographic secret used to compute σ𝜎\sigma. This RoT implementation must be unmodifiable, even when 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s application software is fully compromised. The latter is typically obtained through hardware support, e.g., from ARM TrustZone [46] (see Section II-B) or similar mechanisms.

We observe that the aforementioned 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} notion has important practical limitations. It assumes ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} to be: (1) inputless, i.e., ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} cannot depend on inputs external to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, and (2) stateless, i.e., ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} must not depend on states produced by prior 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instances in 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. As a result, PoX is only suitable for simple self-contained programs that may process locally collected data (via 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} local I/O interfaces) but do not depend on external inputs or prior execution states. This assumption becomes problematic when attempting to apply PoX to FL/LDP.

For FL integrity, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} should prove that a training function ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} was executed on local training dataset D𝐷D using 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-supplied global weights W𝑊W and training parameters. Moreover, no portion of D𝐷D should be revealed to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}, requiring multiple 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instances (e.g., multiple sensing routines executed over time) to correctly produce all data points in D𝐷D. As detailed in Section II-A, similar requirements exist in LDP. Therefore, standard 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} can not be applied in these settings.

I-B Our Contributions

To address the aforementioned limitations, this work introduces the security notion of Proof of Stateful Execution (𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}) to enable input validation and state preservation, in addition to classic PoX guarantees. The former relaxes the constraint of inputless functions in traditional 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}, while the latter ensures that 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} can use 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} pre-existing states as long as they originate from a prior authentic 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} execution. In essence, PoSX offers assurance that execution of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}, computed with authentic input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} and state 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}}, denoted ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}), occurred faithfully, without disclosing 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Figure 2(b) highlights key differences between 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} and 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} at a high level.

To realize 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} on real-world IoT settings, we design and implement 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}: a System-Level Approach for Poisoning Prevention. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s design and security rely on the commercially available TrustZone-M Security Extension, widely present even in low-end embedded devices: those based on ARM Cortex-M Micro-Controller Units (MCUs). This facilitates the immediate real-world implementation of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} onto current IoT devices.

We show that 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} can support a wide range of data collection schemes, including FL and LDP, all with poisoning-free guarantees. Compared to prior data-centric mitigations in FL [50, 6, 33] or LDP [7], 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} offers two key benefits: it is agnostic to the underlying collection scheme (and implementation thereof), thereby capable of supporting both FL and LDP without changes in its trusted code base (TCB); it approaches the problem from a system security perspective, requiring no assumptions about the underlying data and its distribution. In summary, our anticipated contributions are the following:

  1. 1.

    New 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} Security Notion: we define a new security primitive, called Proof of Stateful Execution (𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}). 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} retains the same guarantees as classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} while addressing its limitations of inputless and stateless execution and maintaining privacy of underlying execution states vis-a-vis 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

  2. 2.

    Practical Poisoning Prevention: We develop 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}: a design to realize 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} that is applicable to resource-constrained embedded devices. We integrate 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} with FL and LDP implementations to support poison-free instantiations of these algorithms without loss of privacy.

  3. 3.

    Real-World Prototypes: To validate 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} and foster reproducibility, we provide three implementations, each utilizing distinct cryptographic schemes: symmetric, traditional asymmetric, and quantum-resistant asymmetric primitives. These implementations are prototyped and opensourced [3] using a real-world IoT development board: SAML11 Xplained Pro [36].

  4. 4.

    Evaluation: We conduct various experiments to assess 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s efficiency. Our results demonstrate small runtime and memory overhead atop the baseline, in exchange for increased security and flexibility. Finally, we provide detailed case studies highlighting 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s efficacy in thwarting poisoning attacks within FL/LDP.

II Background

II-A Privacy-Preserving Data Collection Schemes

In this section, we overview FL and LDP. We use the notation ϕitalic-ϕ\phi to indicate an empty/null variable. 

Local Differential Privacy-based Data Collection (LDP-DC): The goal of this scheme is for an IoT sensor, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, to output a noisy sensor value 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} such that it preserves ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP; informally speaking, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP guarantees that 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} leaks no information about its original value 𝒪′superscript𝒪′{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}^{\prime} except with a small probability constrained by ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. At the same time, collecting 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} from a large number of 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-s allows 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} to obtain certain statistics of the collected sensor values with high confidence. Various LDP mechanisms have been proposed to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP in different settings. As an example case, we focus on the LDP mechanism called Basic RAPPOR [22] noting that the concepts introduced in this work can be generalized to other LDP-based mechanisms.

LDP-DC, as detailed in Algorithm 1, describes how 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} performs data collection using Basic RAPPOR. First, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} collects a sensor reading 𝒪′superscript𝒪′{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}^{\prime} by calling the sensor function ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} on a given input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}, i.e., ℱ​(ℐ)ℱℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}). Assuming 𝒪′superscript𝒪′{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}^{\prime} can be represented using k𝑘k-bit unsigned integer, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} next performs a unary encoding (U​E𝑈𝐸UE) that transforms 𝒪′superscript𝒪′{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}^{\prime} into a 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}-bit vector b𝑏b in which only the 𝒪t​hsuperscript𝒪𝑡ℎ{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}^{th} bit is set to 1 and other bits are 0.

Next, on input b𝑏b and LDP parameter f𝑓f, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} invokes Permanent Randomized Response (P​R​R𝑃𝑅𝑅PRR) function and produces a 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}-bit noisy vector b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime} as output, where bi′subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖b^{\prime}_{i} – the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} bit of b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime} – is computed as:

bi′={1,with probability ​f20,with probability ​f2bi,with probability ​1−fsubscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖cases1with probability 𝑓20with probability 𝑓2subscript𝑏𝑖with probability 1𝑓\footnotesize b^{\prime}_{i}=\begin{cases}1,&\text{with probability }\frac{f}{2}\\ 0,&\text{with probability }\frac{f}{2}\\ b_{i},&\text{with probability }1-f\\ \end{cases} (1)

Once b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime} is generated, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} caches an input-output mapping (b𝑏b, b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime}) to a local state variable B𝐵B (i.e., B​[b]=b′𝐵delimited-[]𝑏superscript𝑏′B[b]=b^{\prime}) and, for all future encounters of the same input b𝑏b, returns B​[b]𝐵delimited-[]𝑏B[b] without recomputing the entire P​R​R𝑃𝑅𝑅PRR function.

Finally, on input b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime} and LDP parameters p𝑝p and q𝑞q, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} executes Instantaneous Randomized Response (I​R​R𝐼𝑅𝑅IRR) function that returns a 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}-bit binary vector 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} such that:

ℙ​(𝒪i=1)={p,if ​bi′=1q,otherwiseℙsubscript𝒪𝑖1cases𝑝if subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖1𝑞otherwise\footnotesize\mathbb{P}({\sf{\mathcal{O}}}_{i}=1)=\begin{cases}p,&\text{if }b^{\prime}_{i}=1\\ q,&\text{otherwise}\end{cases} (2)

Using LDP-DC, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} can estimate f~xsubscript~𝑓𝑥\tilde{f}_{x}, the frequency of sensor value x𝑥x by:

f~x=cx−(q+12​f​p−12​f​q)​n(1−f)​(p−q)​nsubscript~𝑓𝑥subscript𝑐𝑥𝑞12𝑓𝑝12𝑓𝑞𝑛1𝑓𝑝𝑞𝑛\footnotesize\tilde{f}_{x}=\dfrac{c_{x}-(q+\frac{1}{2}fp-\frac{1}{2}fq)n}{(1-f)(p-q)n} (3)

where cxsubscript𝑐𝑥c_{x} represents the number of reports that have xt​hsuperscript𝑥𝑡ℎx^{th} bit set and n𝑛n is the number of reports received by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. We refer the interested reader to the Basic RAPPOR paper [22] for details on how to select f,p,q𝑓𝑝𝑞f,p,q to satisfy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP.

Importantly, privacy in this scheme requires 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} to be oblivious to B𝐵B; otherwise, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} can reverse the P​R​R𝑃𝑅𝑅PRR operation to recover the original sensor reading 𝒪′superscript𝒪′{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}^{\prime}. Also, this scheme requires multiple input arguments as part of its execution (i.e., LDP parameters f𝑓f, p𝑝p, and q𝑞q). As noted earlier, however, standard PoX does not support execution using external input arguments or 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} local states that must be oblivious to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. 

Federated Learning-based data collection (FL-DC): Contrary to LDP-DC, FL-DC [30] requires 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} to send a locally trained machine learning (ML) partial model to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} instead of sensor readings. This keeps raw sensor data local to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} and not directly accessible by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

A typical FL-DC consists of two phases depicted in Algorithm 2. In the first phase, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} invokes the Sense-Store function to collect a raw sensor reading and store it in a local list D𝐷D. This phase can be repeated multiple times over a certain period to collect more training data on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Once a sufficient amount of training data is gathered, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} receives globally trained weights W𝑊W from 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} along with the training parameters (t𝑡t and α𝛼\alpha). It then triggers the Train function that utilizes W𝑊W as a base model to train the data in D𝐷D. This function outputs the locally trained weights 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} without disclosing D𝐷D to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

After collecting weights 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}-s from multiple devices, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} can aggregate them using several methods, e.g., FedAvg [30] averages the received weights and sets the result as the new global weights: W←W+η⋅∑i=1m(𝒪i−W)/m←𝑊𝑊⋅𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝒪𝑖𝑊𝑚W\leftarrow W+\eta\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{m}({\sf{\mathcal{O}}}_{i}-W)/m for some global learning rate η𝜂\eta.

Similar to LDP-DC, executing FL-DC functions relies on both input arguments (i.e., training input arguments W𝑊W, t𝑡t and α𝛼\alpha, as well as 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-local state D𝐷D). Consequently, FL-DC integration with classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} faces the same challenges as LDP-DC.

II-B ARM TrustZone-M Security Extensions

ARM TrustZone-M is a hardware security extension that enables a trusted execution environment (TEE) in ARM Cortex-M MCUs commonly used in low-cost and energy-efficient IoT applications. TrustZone divides software states into two isolated worlds: Secure and Non-Secure. The Non-Secure world contains and executes (untrusted) application software while security-critical (trusted) software is stored and runs in the Secure world.

In particular, we leverage two security properties of ARM TrustZone-M in this work:

  • •

    Hardware-enforces World Isolation. TrustZone-M ensures complete isolation of these worlds by implementing several hardware controls (i.e., TZASC, TZMA modules) to enforce access control to hardware resources (e.g., program and data memory, peripherals) for these two worlds. With isolation in place, TrustZone ensures the Non-Secure World is unable to access any code and data located in the Secure World. This assures that the Secure world remains secure even if an adversary can fully modify or compromise the Non-Secure world software state.

  • •

    Controlled Invocation. In TrustZone-M, the only legal way for the non-secure world to access a function inside the secure world is by issuing the Security Monitor Call (SMC) instruction. This instruction provides a secure context switch to the secure world. In addition, the SMC instruction ensures correct invocation of the secure world’s functions, i.e., it always invokes this function at its first legal instruction while prohibiting a jump to the middle of the function.

III System Model and Assumptions

III-A Network and Usage Model

We consider an IoT setting as shown earlier in Figure 1, consisting of two entity types: one 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and multiple 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-s. 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} is a resource-constrained sensor deployed in a physical space of interest, e.g., a smart home, office, or factory. 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} is a remote service provider that orchestrates these 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-s. As an example, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-s could be smart light bulbs that are used in many smart homes and can be controlled by the end-user through Philips 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}’s application services; or Samsung could act as 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that provides a service for the end-user to command all SmartThings-compatible devices.

Besides offering this service, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} wishes to collect sensor data generated by 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-s to further improve the service performance or enhance the user experience. In the context of this work, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} has the option to employ LDP-DC or FL-DC as its preferred data collection scheme, depending on the desired outcome and privacy considerations. As poisoning attacks could sabotage the collection outcome, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} also aims to detect and prevent such attacks to safeguard the authenticity of the outcomes.

III-B Adversary Model

We consider an 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} who can modify/compromise 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s application software at will. Once compromised, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} can access, modify, or erase any code or data in 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} unless explicitly protected by hardware-enforced access control rules. Consequently, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} may use this ability to perform poisoning attacks by corrupting a sensor function ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} or its execution to spoof arbitrary results sent to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Invasive hardware-based/physical attacks (e.g., fault-injection attacks or physical hardware manipulation) are out of scope in this work, as they require orthogonal tamper-proofing techniques [47].

We also assume 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} has full control over the communication channel between 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} and 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. They may perform any network-based attacks, e.g., reading, modifying, replaying, or dropping any message sent from/to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}.

Finally, in line with the standard LDP and FL 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} models, we also consider the possibility of malicious 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. In the latter, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}’s goal is to learn sensitive data on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, which could be accomplished by exploiting weaknesses in the underlying data collection scheme.

III-C Device Model

𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-s are small embedded/IoT devices equipped with TrustZone-M, e.g., ARM embedded devices running on Cortex-M23/33 MCUs, which are optimized for low-cost and energy efficiency. Following the PoX assumption [13], we assume that the function whose execution is being proven (ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}, i.e., the code implementing the data collection task according to the underlying scheme) is correct and contains no implementation bug that can lead to run-time exploits within itself. In practice, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} can employ various pre-deployment vulnerability detection techniques to fulfill this requirement [10].

We also adhere to standard TEE-based security assumptions, i.e., we assume the small TCB implementing the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} RoT located inside TrustZone’s Secure World is trusted and TrustZone hardware modules are implemented correctly such that 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} cannot modify this RoT implementation or violate any security guarantees implemented by the Secure World-resident code. The latter implies the existence of secure persistent storage, exclusively accessible by the Secure World and unmodifiable when the device is offline. This storage is used to store our TCB along with a counter-based challenge c𝑐c and two cryptographic keys: 𝗌𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏subscript𝗌𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{sk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}} and 𝗉𝗄𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝗉𝗄𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}}}, where 𝗌𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏subscript𝗌𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{sk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}} corresponds to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} private key, whose public counterpart 𝗉𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏subscript𝗉𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}} is known to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Similarly, 𝗉𝗄𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝗉𝗄𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}}} denotes 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} public key with its private counterpart 𝗌𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏subscript𝗌𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{sk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}} securely managed by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. In TrustZone-M implementations, secure persistent memory is supported by a standard secure boot architecture [4] with the physical memory storing cryptographic keys being physically inaccessible through I/O interfaces (e.g., USB/J-TAG, etc.).

Finally, we assume these keys are correctly distributed to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} out-of-band, e.g., by physically fusing these keys on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} during manufacture time or using any key-provisioning mechanism [37] after 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} deployment.

IV 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} and Associated Definitions

To define 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} security goal, we start by revisiting classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} guarantees and their limitations. Then we formulate auxiliary notions that address each limitation and in conjunction imply 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} end-to-end goal.

{definition}

[PoX Security]Let ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} represent an arbitrary software function (code) execution of which is requested by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, producing output 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}. A protocol is considered PoX-secure if and only if the protocol outputting ⊤top\top implies:

  1. (i)

    ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} code (as defined by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}) executes atomically and completely between 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} sending a request and receiving the response, and

  2. (ii)

    𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is a direct outcome of this execution of ℱ​()ℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}().

Definition IV states the classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security notion, as described in [13]. A violation of conditions (i) or (ii) in Definition IV must be detectable by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}, resulting in a protocol abort (i.e., by outputting ⊥bottom\bot). As discussed in [13], this notion can be used to construct “sensors that cannot lie” irrespective of compromised software states. However, it only supports self-contained IoT applications that are independent of 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-defined inputs or pre-computed states due to two limitations:

L1 – Lack of input validation. Definition IV considers inputless ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} functions. This is because classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} does not support verification of the origin and integrity of inputs received by 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. This limitation is significant for applications where 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} must provide input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} as part of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} (e.g., FL/LDP cases discussed in Sec. II-A).

L2 – No state preservation across 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instances. Definition IV only supports 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} of stateless ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} functions. In other words, ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} must rely solely on data generated/acquired within its current execution instance and must not depend on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} states (denoted 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}}) produced by prior executions. Similar to L1 case, a 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} protocol satisfying Definition IV provides no guarantee or validation to the correct use of some pre-existent/expected state 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} in 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Thus, attacks that tamper with 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} in between subsequent 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instances may result in illegal alteration of the end result 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}.

Remark: note that when 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} contains only public information, L2 can be obviated by L1 by making 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} a part of the authenticated output of a 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instance and used as a 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-defined input to ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} in a subsequent 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instance. However, when 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} contains information that must remain hidden from 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} (the case of our target applications – recall Sec. II-A), consistency of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} must be ensured locally at 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, making L1 and L2 independent challenges.

To address these limitations systematically, we introduce two new 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}-related security notions. As these notions may be of independent interest, we first present them separately and finally compose them into an end-to-end 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} goal.

{definition}

[IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} Security]Let ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} represent an arbitrary software function (code) and ℐℐ{\sf{\mathcal{I}}} represent an input, both defined by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Let 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} represent the output and σ𝜎\sigma denote a proof of ℱ​(ℐ)ℱℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) execution produced by 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. A protocol is considered IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}-secure if and only if the protocol outputting ⊤top\top implies:

  1. (i)

    ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} executes with input arguments ℐℐ{\sf{\mathcal{I}}}, atomically and completely between 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} sending the request and receiving σ𝜎\sigma, and

  2. (ii)

    𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is a direct outcome of this ℱ​(ℐ)ℱℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) execution

To overcome L1, we present the notion of input-validating 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} (or IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}), as shown in Definition IV. In IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} aims to execute ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} with its own provided input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}. Thus, the proof generated by 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, σ𝜎\sigma, must not only validate atomic and complete execution of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} but also that it was invoked with the correct input requested by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} (as captured in condition (i) of Definition IV). Thus, an IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} protocol must ensure 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} authenticity concerning ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}, i.e., 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is generated by executing ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} correctly using the expected input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}.

{definition}

[SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} Security]Let ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} represent an arbitrary software function (code) requested by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} to run on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} with state 𝒮𝒮{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}, where 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} was produced by some prior 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} but is oblivious to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Let 𝒪𝒪{\sf{\mathcal{O}}} represent the output and σ𝜎\sigma denote a proof of ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} execution produced by 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. A protocol is considered SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}-secure if and only if the protocol outputting ⊤top\top implies:

  1. (i)

    ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} executes atomically and completely between 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} sending the request and receiving σ𝜎\sigma with 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} state corresponding to 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} when ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution starts (denote this execution by ℱ𝒮​()subscriptℱ𝒮{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}()), and

  2. (ii)

    𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is a direct outcome of this ℱ𝒮​()subscriptℱ𝒮{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}() execution, and

  3. (iii)

    𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} cannot infer the value of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} beyond what is revealed by 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, and

  4. (iv)

    𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} was not modified between the current ℱ𝒮​()subscriptℱ𝒮{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}() execution and the prior 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-authorized 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}.

To address L2, we specify the State-Preserving 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} (SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}) notion in Definition IV. Similar to IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security, the SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} notion specifies the first two conditions to ensure that, in addition to atomic ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution, σ𝜎\sigma also conveys two critical aspects: (1) correct use of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} during ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution and (2) dependence of 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} on ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} and 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}}. In addition, it requires 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} privacy vis-a-vis 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and prohibits 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} modification in between subsequent 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} instances.

{definition}

[𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} Security] A scheme is 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}-secure if and only if it satisfies both IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} (Def. IV) and SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} (Def. IV) Security.

Finally, Definition IV combines IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} and SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} to state the goal of 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}-Security.

V 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}: Realizing 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} with TrustZone-M

V-A Overview of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} Workflow

Building on TrustZone-M hardware-enforced world isolation (recall Sec. II-B), our approach is to implement 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s RoT in and execute it from the Secure World. Meanwhile, normal applications are untrusted (hereby referred to as untrusted software) and reside in the Non-Secure World.

𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} implements three Secure World functions: Execute, CheckState, and SetState. Execute serves as the main call to execute ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} and compute a proof of this stateful execution. CheckState and SetState are used to authenticate state 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} used in Execute.

𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} workflow is depicted in Figure 3. At a high level, it enforces the following operation sequence upon receiving a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request from 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.:

  • •

    Upon being called by the Non-Secure World, Execute authenticates 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} request in ❹.

  • •

    Following successful authentication, it starts executing ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) atomically in Non-Secure World, ❺.

  • •

    In order to access 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} in ❻, ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) must call CheckState function in the Secure World. CheckState takes one input argument, representing the current 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value. Its task is to authenticate this value by matching it against the latest benign 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value from a prior execution stored within the Secure World.

  • •

    Similarly, after 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} is modified in ❻, execution is trapped into the Secure World via the SetState function. SetState accepts one input argument: the new 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value. It is responsible for committing and securely maintaining the latest benign 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value in the Secure World.

  • •

    Once ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) execution completes, yielding output 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, the control returns to Execute in ❼. Then, Execute computes σ𝜎\sigma indicating an authenticated proof of this execution in ❽ and returns (𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, σ𝜎\sigma) to the Non-Secure World in ❾, which in turn forwards them to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

With (𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, σ𝜎\sigma), 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} can determine if ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) was executed in 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s Non-Secure World, if 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is an authentic result of this execution, and if 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} was preserved since the prior execution. Importantly, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} assures that σ𝜎\sigma is not computable unless the aforementioned operation sequence is observed.

V-B 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} in Detail

Protocol V-B details the 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} ↔↔\leftrightarrow 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} interation in 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}. 

Phase 1: Request Generation

An instance of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol starts when 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} generates a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request, in Step 1, comprising: (i) an identifier ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} for which function to execute; (ii) input arguments ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}; and (iii) a monotonically-increasing counter-based challenge c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}. This request instructs 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} to execute ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) in the Non-Secure World on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} and return the result to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} along with proof of this expected execution. Following this, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} signs this request (via Sign function), producing token σ𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝜎𝒱𝗋𝖿\sigma_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}, and attaches this token to the request before sending it to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} in Step 2 of Protocol V-B.

Phase 2: Preparation for ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) Execution

In Step 3, untrusted software in 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} must invoke Execute passing the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request as a parameter. In step 4, Execute (i) checks whether the request counter c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} is larger than a local counter c𝑐c maintained by the Secure World to ensure freshness of the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request and prevent replayed attacks; (ii) verifies σ𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝜎𝒱𝗋𝖿\sigma_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} to confirm authenticity of the request; and (iii) checks that no other 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} instance is active by examining e​x​e​c𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐exec flag maintained in the secure world. If any of the checks fail, the process is aborted which implies the inability to produce the end proof σ𝜎\sigma. The same applies if Execute is never called.

If all checks succeed, Execute updates the local counter with c𝑐c with c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} and initializes three Secure World flags in Step 5:

  • •

    e​x​e​c𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐exec is set to ⊤top\top, indicating an active 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} instance.

  • •

    s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑stateChecked is set to ⊥bottom\bot, indicating the status of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} authenticity during ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution.

  • •

    s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑stateUsed is set to ⊥bottom\bot, indicating the status of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} access during ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution.

In Step 6, Execute prepares 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} for the upcoming execution of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} by disabling all interrupts and taking a snapshot (hℎh) as a hash digest reflecting the states of the Non-Secure World’s binary code in program memory (P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM) and the parameters received in the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request. It then calls ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} on input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} in the Non-Secure World (Step 7).

To leverage 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}, the implementation of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} must:

  • B1:

    At the start of its execution, validate relevant state 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} authenticity by calling CheckState.

  • B2:

    At the end of its execution, commit the latest 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value to the Secure World by invoking SetState.

  • B3:

    Throughout its execution, ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} must never enable interrupts.

Phase 3: ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) Execution

From B1, it follows that a call to ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}, in Step 8, triggers CheckState of current 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}}. In Step 9, CheckState, executed in the Secure World, sets s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑stateUsed to ⊤top\top and proceeds to verify authenticity of the current 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value, s𝑠s, by comparing s𝑠s with the latest benign 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value, 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}, stored in the Secure World. Only if they match, CheckState ascertains s𝑠s authenticity setting s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑stateChecked to ⊤top\top. Execution of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} is then resumed. From B2, SetState is invoked at the end of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution to update 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} with the new state s𝑠s if and only if (s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d=e​x​e​c=⊤𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐topstateChecked=exec=\top). To optimize storage, especially when |s|𝑠|s| is large, SetState can update 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} with a hash of s𝑠s, as shown in Step 11. This storage optimization comes with the expense of additional runtime overhead for hash computations in CheckState and SetState. We discuss this time-space trade-off further in Section VII.

ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution completes producing the output 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} and handing the control to Execute with 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} as an input in Step 12.

Phase 4: Proof Generation

Execute examines e​x​e​c𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐exec, s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑stateUsed, and s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑stateChecked flags to determine the occurrence of the CheckState →→\rightarrow SetState sequence. If this sequence is maintained during ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution, Execute proceeds to compute the proof σ𝜎\sigma in Step 13 by signing hℎh and 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} using 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s private key 𝗌𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏subscript𝗌𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏{\sf{sk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}}}. Execute resets all Secure World flags before returning to the Non-Secure World with 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} and σ𝜎\sigma, in Step 15. They are then transmitted to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}, in Step 16.

Protocol 1: 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} Protocol
Verifier (𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}) (1) Generate an authenticated 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request: σ𝒱​𝗋𝖿←Sign​(𝗌𝗄𝒱​𝗋𝖿,H​(ℱ,ℐ,c𝒱​𝗋𝖿))←subscript𝜎𝒱𝗋𝖿Signsubscript𝗌𝗄𝒱𝗋𝖿Hℱℐsubscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿\sigma_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}\leftarrow\textsf{Sign}({\sf{sk_{{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}}}},\textsf{H}({\sf{\mathcal{F}}},{\sf{\mathcal{I}}},c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}})) (2) Send (σ𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝜎𝒱𝗋𝖿\sigma_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}, ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}, ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}, c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}) to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} - Prover (𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}) In Non-Secure World: (3) Call Execute in Secure World with the received request In Execute function, Secure World: (4) Authenticate the request and abort if r=⊥𝑟bottomr=\bot or e​x​e​c=⊤𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐topexec=\top: r←(c𝒱​𝗋𝖿>c)∧Verify​(𝗉𝗄𝒱​𝗋𝖿,σ𝒱​𝗋𝖿,ℱ,ℐ,c𝒱​𝗋𝖿)←𝑟subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿𝑐Verifysubscript𝗉𝗄𝒱𝗋𝖿subscript𝜎𝒱𝗋𝖿ℱℐsubscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿r\leftarrow(c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}>c)\land\textsf{Verify}({\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}}}},\sigma_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}},{\sf{\mathcal{F}}},{\sf{\mathcal{I}}},c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}) (5) Update counter: c←c𝒱​𝗋𝖿←𝑐subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c\leftarrow c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} and initialize: e​x​e​c←⊤←𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐topexec\leftarrow\top, s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d←⊥←𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑bottomstateUsed\leftarrow\bot s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d←⊥←𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑bottomstateChecked\leftarrow\bot (6) Disable interrupts and measure P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM and 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} request: h←H​(P​M​E​M,ℱ,ℐ,c𝒱​𝗋𝖿)←ℎH𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀ℱℐsubscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿h\leftarrow\textsf{H}(PMEM,{\sf{\mathcal{F}}},{\sf{\mathcal{I}}},c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}}) (7) Call ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) in Non-Secure World In ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} function, Non-Secure World: (8) Run ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}). Pass control to the Secure World when CheckState(s𝑠s) is called In CheckState function, Secure World: (9) Perform an integrity check on s𝑠s, store the result to p𝑝p and return to Non-Secure World: s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d←(H​(s)=?𝒮s​e​c)←𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑superscript?H𝑠subscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐stateChecked\leftarrow(\textsf{H}(s)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle?}}{{=}}{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}). Also, set s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d←⊤←𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑topstateUsed\leftarrow\top. In ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} function, Non-Secure World: (10) Continue with ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) execution. Pass control to the Secure World when SetState(s𝑠s) is called In SetState function, Secure World: (11) Securely set 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} based on input s𝑠s and return to Non-Secure World: 𝒮s​e​c←H​(s)​ if ​(s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d∧e​x​e​c)←subscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐H𝑠 if 𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}\leftarrow\textsf{H}(s)\text{ if }(stateChecked\land exec) In ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} function, Non-Secure World: (12) Continue with ℱ𝒮​(ℐ)subscriptℱ𝒮ℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}_{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) until the execution is completed, producing output 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, and then return to its caller, Execute, with 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} In Execute function, Secure World: (13) Abort if (e​x​e​c∧s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d∧¬s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d)𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑(exec~{}\land stateUsed~{}\land\neg stateChecked). Otherwise, include 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} to the measurement and compute the proof: σ←Sign​(𝗌𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏,H​(h,𝒪))←𝜎Signsubscript𝗌𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏Hℎ𝒪\sigma\leftarrow\textsf{Sign}({\sf{sk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}}},\textsf{H}(h,{\sf{\mathcal{O}}})) (14) Reset all flags: e​x​e​c←⊥,s​t​a​t​e​C​h​e​c​k​e​d←⊥,s​t​a​t​e​U​s​e​d←⊥formulae-sequence←𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐bottomformulae-sequence←𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘𝑒𝑑bottom←𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑈𝑠𝑒𝑑bottomexec\leftarrow\bot,stateChecked\leftarrow\bot,stateUsed\leftarrow\bot (15) Enable interrupts and return with (𝒪,σ)𝒪𝜎({\sf{\mathcal{O}}},\sigma) In Non-Secure World: (16) Forward (𝒪,σ)𝒪𝜎({\sf{\mathcal{O}}},\sigma) to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} - Verifier (𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}) (17) Increment c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} and validate σ𝜎\sigma by: r←ValidatePoSX​(𝗉𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏,σ,P​M​E​M′,ℱ,ℐ,c𝒱​𝗋𝖿,𝒪)←𝑟ValidatePoSXsubscript𝗉𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏𝜎𝑃𝑀𝐸superscript𝑀′ℱℐsubscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿𝒪r\leftarrow\textsf{ValidatePoSX}({\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}}},\sigma,PMEM^{\prime},{\sf{\mathcal{F}}},{\sf{\mathcal{I}}},c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}},{\sf{\mathcal{O}}}) The protocol outputs r𝑟r.

Phase 5: Proof Validation

Upon receiving 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} and σ𝜎\sigma, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} increments c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} and performs the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} verification in Step 17 by:

  • •

    Checking validity of σ𝜎\sigma. As 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} possesses the expected binary of 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s Non-Secure World, P​M​E​M′𝑃𝑀𝐸superscript𝑀′PMEM^{\prime}, this verification involves checking σ𝜎\sigma against P​M​E​M′𝑃𝑀𝐸superscript𝑀′PMEM^{\prime}, ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}, ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}}, c𝒱​𝗋𝖿subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}} and 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} using 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s public key 𝗉𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏subscript𝗉𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏{\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}}}, i.e.:

    Verify​(𝗉𝗄𝒫​𝗋𝗏,σ,P​M​E​M′,ℱ,ℐ,𝒪,c𝒱​𝗋𝖿)=?⊤superscript?Verifysubscript𝗉𝗄𝒫𝗋𝗏𝜎𝑃𝑀𝐸superscript𝑀′ℱℐ𝒪subscript𝑐𝒱𝗋𝖿top\textsf{Verify}({\sf{pk_{{\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}}}}},\sigma,PMEM^{\prime},{\sf{\mathcal{F}}},{\sf{\mathcal{I}}},{\sf{\mathcal{O}}},c_{\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle?}}{{=}}\top

  • •

    Inspect ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} binary to ensure that it adheres to the expected behaviors: B1, B2 and B3.

Finally, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol is considered successful and thus outputs ⊤top\top if it passes both checks; it aborts with ⊥bottom\bot otherwise.

VI 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} Security Analysis

Our security argument is based on the following properties:

P1 - Request Verification. In 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s TCB always verifies freshness and authenticity of a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request before executing ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} and generating the proof σ𝜎\sigma. This prevents 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} from exploiting forged or replayed requests to manipulate the protocol outcome. See step 4 of Protocol V-B.

P2 - Input Validation. A valid σ𝜎\sigma serves as authentication for the correct usage of ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} during ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution. This prevents 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} from feeding malicious input to ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} while still succeeding in the 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol. Since ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} is included in a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request, this is implied by P1 and the fact that ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} is directly used by 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} to invoke ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} in step 7 of Protocol V-B.

P3 - State Privacy. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protects privacy of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} from 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} since the only information 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} receives are 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} and σ𝜎\sigma. In cases that 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} can be leaked through 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} has the option to refuse to send it over to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} by simply terminating the protocol. Moreover, since σ𝜎\sigma is not a function of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}}, it leaks no information about 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

P4 - State Authenticity. In 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}, the successful completion of a protocol instance guarantees the 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value, stored in the Non-Secure World, is authentic, i.e., it can only be modified by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-approved software during a protocol instance and remains unchanged between consecutive instances. This assurance comes from two observations:

First, 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} always corresponds to the latest benign 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value because: (1) 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} cannot be updated outside a protocol instance due to the check of e​x​e​c𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐exec flag in Step 11; and (2) 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} cannot be influenced by forged or replayed 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} requests since the request is always authenticated in Step 4 before e​x​e​c𝑒𝑥𝑒𝑐exec can be set in Step 5.

Second, any unauthorized modification to 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} outside a protocol instance is detected in the subsequent instance by CheckState due to a mismatch between the 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value and 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}. As a successful 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol implies a successful check from CheckState, 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} must be equal to 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}, and, according to the first observation, must contain the latest authentic 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value. Moreover, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} may attempt to tamper with 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} while ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} is executing. However, doing so requires modification to P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM, which would result in a mismatch with P​M​E​M′𝑃𝑀𝐸superscript𝑀′PMEM^{\prime} during the proof validation in Step 17.

P5 - Atomic Execution. ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution must occur atomically; otherwise, the protocol must fail. This is required to prevent 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} from interrupting ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution to tamper with its data and execution flows, influencing the outcome. Step 6 realizes this requirement by disabling all interrupts before ℱℱ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}} invocation. We explain how this requirement can be relaxed in Section VII.

P6 - Output Authenticity. A successful 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol indicates to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is authentic and generated by executing ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} atomically with the 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-specified ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} and the correct state 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}}. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} satisfies this property since P1 guarantees that ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} is always invoked with authentic ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} and P5 enforces ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} to execute without interruptions before immediately returning to Secure World with 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}. This leaves no opportunities for untrusted software to interrupt ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution to tamper with 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}. 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} attempt to change 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} via 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} are prevented by P4. 

Security Argument. We show that 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} satisfies both Definition IV and Definition IV implying adherence to Definition IV. Per Definition IV, IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security requires 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} assurance for stateless ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} functions that run with input arguments, i.e., when 𝒮=ϕ𝒮italic-ϕ{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}=\phi and ℐ≠ϕℐitalic-ϕ{\sf{\mathcal{I}}}\neq\phi. In this scenario, P2 and P5 ensure the atomic execution of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} with the authentic input ℐℐ\sf{\mathcal{I}} provided by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}, satisfying condition (i). P6 guarantees that 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is generated as a result of ℱ​(ℐ)ℱℐ{\sf{\mathcal{F}}}({\sf{\mathcal{I}}}) execution, fulfilling condition (ii). With both conditions met, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} achieves IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security. Meanwhile, SV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security in Definition IV requires secure 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} of a stateful ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} executed without input arguments. Similar to the previous argument, P5 and P6 directly address conditions (i) and (ii) of SV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security even when ℐ=ϕℐitalic-ϕ{\sf{\mathcal{I}}}=\phi. As P3 ensures 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} privacy, it fulfills condition (iii). Also, P4 guarantees that 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} cannot be modified except by a fresh instance of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol, which satisfies condition (iv). Meeting all conditions in Definition IV, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} is also SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX}-secure. Lastly, 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} security (per Definition IV) follows directly from simultaneous adherence to IV-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} and SP-𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} security.∎

VII 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} Extensions and Variations

Cryptographic Choices. Although Protocol V-B uses public-key cryptography, it can seamlessly transition to symmetric cryptography by simply substituting public-key operations (i.e., Sign and Verify) with MAC operations. If quantum threats are in scope, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} can be similarly adjusted to support a post-quantum signature scheme. We demonstrate this versatility by implementing our prototype (Section IX) using three distinct cryptographic choices (public-key, symmetric, and post-quantum cryptography).

Space-Time Trade-Off. Section V-B discussed choices for managing 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec} in the Secure World: (1) storing the entire 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value; or (2) maintaining a hash of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} value. The first prioritizes runtime efficiency since it requires no run-time hash computation while the second conserves storage in the Secure World by condensing the potentially large 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} into a fixed-size digest. A third option, that eliminates storage in the Secure World, is to have SetState compute a MAC of 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} (instead of a hash) and pass it back to the Non-Secure World for storage. Subsequently, the Secure World can authenticate 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} received from the Normal World based on the MAC, yielding equivalent security guarantees as the previous two approaches. By default, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} prototype adopts the second design choice, striking a balance between space and time overhead.

Multiple Stateful Functions. Our description of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} assumes that 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} intends to obtain one 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} per 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} at a time. Nonetheless, it can be extended to accommodate simultaneous 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}-s by maintaining a map between multiple 𝒮s​e​csubscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}-s and each ongoing 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}, in the Secure World. To that end, CheckState and SetState should be extended to assign 𝒮s​e​c=m​a​p​[i​d]subscript𝒮𝑠𝑒𝑐𝑚𝑎𝑝delimited-[]𝑖𝑑{\sf{\mathcal{S}}}_{sec}=map[id] for a given function identifier i​d𝑖𝑑id. Also, in the last step of the protocol, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} must additionally inspect ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} binary to ensure that it correctly calls CheckState and SetState with the correct function identifier.

Relaxing Atomicity Requirement. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} security mandates atomicity (uninterruptability) during ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution. This requirement may clash with real-time needs on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, potentially preventing time-sensitive tasks from completing while 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} is running. Recent studies [8, 40] propose techniques to relax this atomicity requirement in classic 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} and related schemes. These can also be adopted in 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} as follows: rather than completely disabling interrupts, the Secure World “locks” (i.e., making them read-only) P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM, data currently in use by the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} task, and the Interrupt Vector Table (IVT). It also includes IVT in the snapshot hℎh before invoking ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}. As a consequence, the 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} context is protected across interrupts. Once ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} completes, respective memory can be unlocked.

VIII From 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} to Poisoning Prevention

We now discuss how 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} can be leveraged to detect poisoning attacks. Unlike prior work, this guarantee extends to arbitrary functions ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}, whether they require private states or input arguments to execute. To illustrate this, we present LDP-DC+ and FL-DC+, the poisoning-free versions of LDP-DC and FL-DC, respectively.

VIII-A Poisoning-free LDP.

LDP-DC+ utilizes 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} to ensure the correct execution of LDP phases:

  1. 1.

    Setup. Run 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol to obtain a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of Init-state that initializes P​R​R𝑃𝑅𝑅PRR mapping B𝐵B to an empty list on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Abort if the protocol outputs ⊥bottom\bot.

  2. 2.

    Collect. Run 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol to obtain a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of stateful LDP-DC function (in Algorithm 1) to perform a sensor reading and apply the LDP mechanism to it, returning the noisy output 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Repeat this step if 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} wants to collect more sensor readings.

𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} in Setup phase ensures that the state variable B𝐵B is initialized to an empty value. During Collect phase, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol gives assurance to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that: (1) 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} is genuine, originating from a timely execution of the sensor function, and correctly privatized by the underlying LDP mechanism, (2) B𝐵B corresponded to the authentic value (e.g., empty in the first time of this phase’s execution) right before and during the protocol execution, and (3) B𝐵B is correctly updated as a result of the protocol execution. These prevent poisoning attacks because 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} can tamper with neither 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} (during Collect) nor B𝐵B (during Setup or Collect).

VIII-B Poisoning-free FL.

FL-DC+ follows a similar approach by using 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} to convey to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} the correct execution of:

  1. 1.

    Setup. Run 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol to obtain a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of Init-State function that initializes the local training dataset D𝐷D to an empty list on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Abort if the protocol outputs ⊥bottom\bot.

  2. 2.

    Collect. To perform a sensor reading and record the result to D𝐷D, run 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} to obtain a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of Sense-Store (see Algorithm 2). Repeat this step to collect more sensor readings. Abort if the protocol outputs ⊥bottom\bot.

  3. 3.

    Train. Run 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol to obtain a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of Train (see Algorithm 2) that performs a local training on D𝐷D and output the locally trained model 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.

Similar to LDP-DC+, Setup guarantees to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that D𝐷D starts empty. For Collect, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} ensures that each record in D𝐷D is produced as a result of executing the expected sensor function on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Finally, Train assures 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that the correct training function was applied to the authentic training data in D𝐷D, leading to the received trained model 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}}. In the context of FL, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏𝒜𝖽𝗏\sf{\mathcal{A}dv} may attempt poisoning attacks in two ways: (1) model poisoning by directly tampering with the trained model 𝒪𝒪\sf{\mathcal{O}} and (2) data poisoning by manipulating the dataset D𝐷D used for training. Both are prevented by LDP-DC+.

Remark. We emphasize that both LDP-DC+ and FL-DC+ maintain the privacy of their original counterparts. The only additional information obtained by 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} is σσ\sigma, which is not a function of the underlying execution state. Also, as a system-level approach, these schemes offer a deterministic guarantee in differentiating poisoned data from authentic data, i.e., achieving 100% true positive and true negative rates, without relying on any assumptions about the underlying data.

IX Evaluation

IX-A Experimental Setup

Cryptographic Variants: As noted in Section VII, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} is agnostic to underlying cryptographic primitives. To showcase this flexibility, we provide 3 implementation variants of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s RoT: 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK}, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK}, and 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ}:

  1. 1.

    𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} uses symmetric-key cryptography to implement Sign and Verify in Protocol V-B with an HMAC-SHA256 in line with prior 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} work [13].

  2. 2.

    𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK} relies on the public-key signature ECDSA NIST256p from micro-ECC library111https://github.com/kmackay/micro-ecc, which is commonly used in embedded settings [49, 39].

  3. 3.

    𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ} implements Sign and Verify using the quantum-resistant public-key signature Sphincs+, a low-RAM version of Sphincs-sha2-128f222https://github.com/sphincs/low-ram-sphincsplus. This choice is supported by prior research [41, 26] showing feasibility of Sphincs+ on the target ARM Cortex-M devices.

Prototype. We prototype 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} variants on SAML11 Xplained Pro [36] development board as a representative of resource-constrained IoT devices. It features TrustZone-M on an ARM Cortex-M23 MCU @ 32MHz clock, with 64KB of FLASH (of which we assign 32KB to store the Non-secure World’s PMEM) and 16KB of RAM. To accurately isolate 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} base overhead, we implement a simple stateful ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} function on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} that takes input from a GPIO port specified from a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request, performs a sensor reading on that port, and outputs an accumulative sum of all readings over time to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} is deployed as a commodity desktop equipped with an Intel i7-8809G CPU @ 3.10GHz and 32GB RAM. 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} are connected via serial communication. All prototypes are open-sourced and publicly available at [3].

IX-B Baseline.

For comparison, we consider an alternative naive baseline approach in which all functions to prove execution ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} are included as part of TCB residing within the Secure World. To perform 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}, TCB receives and authenticates a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request from the Non-Secure World, just like 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}. Unlike 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}, this approach executes ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} inside the Secure World, The result is signed (or MAC’ed) and forwarded to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}, akin to 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}. As this baseline approach is also agnostic to the underlying cryptographic primitives, we refer to 𝖡𝖺𝗌𝖾𝗅𝗂𝗇𝖾𝖲𝖪subscript𝖡𝖺𝗌𝖾𝗅𝗂𝗇𝖾𝖲𝖪\sf{Baseline_{SK}}, 𝖡𝖺𝗌𝖾𝗅𝗂𝗇𝖾𝖯𝖪subscript𝖡𝖺𝗌𝖾𝗅𝗂𝗇𝖾𝖯𝖪\sf{Baseline_{PK}} and 𝖡𝖺𝗌𝖾𝗅𝗂𝗇𝖾𝖯𝖰subscript𝖡𝖺𝗌𝖾𝗅𝗂𝗇𝖾𝖯𝖰\sf{Baseline_{PQ}} as the baseline approaches that utilize symmetric-key cryptography (HMAC-SHA256), public-key cryptography (ECDSA) and post-quantum cryptography (Sphincs+), respectively.

We note that this baseline faces several security and practical downsides. First, its TCB becomes bloated and dependent on multiple untrusted applications by including all ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}-s within the Secure World. This implies that a vulnerability in one of them can compromise all (i.e., violating the principle of least privilege). It also incurs Secure World’s additional storage for maintaining data of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} execution. This reduces available RAM for normal applications in the Non-Secure World. Moreover, it makes the Secure World code (which should be immutable post-deployment – recall Section II-B) application-specific and thus requires rewriting/updating the Secure World every time to support new applications, which may necessitate cumbersome physical intervention.

IX-C Space Overhead

Code Size. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s TCB was implemented in C and compiled using the O3 optimization flag. Details of code size and the resulting binaries are shown in Table I. As 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} relies on an inexpensive cryptographic primitive, it exhibits the smallest code size. Conversely, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ} results in the largest number of lines of C code. However, the O3 optimization was capable of reducing its binary size, making it comparable to that of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK}. Compared to the baseline, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} introduces a small code size overhead, approximately 6% for 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} and 2% for the others.

For ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} instrumentation, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} requires prepending a call to CheckState at the beginning of ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} and another call to SetState before ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} returns. This instrumentation results in only 2 additional lines of C code, enlarging ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}}’s binary (residing in Non-Secure World) by a fixed 44 bytes. 

Memory Usage. Next, we measure the peak amount of Secure World data allocated at runtime. This data consists of all stack and static/global variables (our implementation utilizes no heap allocation). As shown in Figure 4, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} and 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK} use roughly the same amount of data: ≈\approx1.5KB. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ}, on the other hand, requires more than double this amount: ≈\approx3.6KB. Compared to the baseline, our 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} variants incur an additional memory usage ranging from 32 bytes for 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ} to 200 bytes for 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK}. These correspond to << 1.25% of available RAM.

IX-D Time Overhead

As 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} operates on a powerful back-end, its runtime within the 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} protocol is negligible compared to the execution time on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Thus, we focus on measuring 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s execution time (i.e., the runtime time of executing Phases 3, 4, and 5 in Section V). Results are illustrated in Figure 5.

As expected, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} has the fastest runtime: less than half a second. On the other hand, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ} utilizes expensive cryptography and thus incurs the longest execution time of ≈100absent100\approx 100 seconds. 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK} positions between these two, taking around 2.5 seconds.

Since 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} requires 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} to compute a snapshot of P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM as part of proof generation, we conducted an experiment to assess the impact of P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM size on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s execution time. In this experiment, we varied the P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM size from 4KB to 32KB. As depicted in Figure 6, the time to execute this snapshot contributes significantly to the overall execution time when 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} is used. It also shows a linear relationship between execution time and P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM size for 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK}. However, for 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK} and 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ}, this effect is negligible; its runtime has minimal impact on the overall execution time regardless of P​M​E​M𝑃𝑀𝐸𝑀PMEM size.

Also, from Figures 5 and 6, we can conclude that all 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} variants incur a negligible execution time overhead, i.e., <1%absentpercent1<1\%, compared to their baseline counterparts.

IX-E Case Study 1: Local Differential Privacy

In the first case study, we envision the integration of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} within a smart city/grid system. The service provider aims to periodically collect energy consumption data from all smart meters located in individual households to calculate electric bills, forecast load, etc. Previous studies [35, 38] have demonstrated privacy risks by exposing raw energy to the service provider, e.g., with access to such data, the provider could potentially infer users’ habits and behaviors.

To address this privacy concern, one can employ LDP-DC from Algorithm 1. The service provider is also motivated to employ a poisoning-free version, LDP-DC+ as presented in Section VIII-A, to prevent poisoning by detecting malicious outputs from edge devices.

We build a prototype of a smart meter (𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}) based on a SAML11 Xplained Pro development board connecting to a PZEM-004T energy meter module. 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}’s Non-Secure World consists of LDP-DC software (Algorithm 1) and a driver responsible for retrieving energy data from the PZEM-004T module. Meanwhile, the Secure World contains 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK}’s TCB. The service provider (𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}) runs on a commodity desktop and communicates with 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} over serial communication.

During normal (benign) operation, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} execute an instance of LDP-DC+ protocol. This instance begins with the Setup phase, which requires 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of Init-State function to initialize a 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-local state (P​R​R𝑃𝑅𝑅PRR mapping) to zeroes. Since 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} faithfully executes this phase, it completes with ⊤top\top. Upon obtaining the successful output, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} proceeds to the Collect phase, which aims to collect authentic noisy energy data from 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. To achieve this, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} crafts a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request by configuring a function to prove execution to LDP-DC and properly selecting LDP input parameters (i.e., f𝑓f, p𝑝p and q𝑞q) to meet the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP requirement, and sends an authenticated 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Adhering to the protocol, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} executes LDP-DC correctly (with 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-defined inputs) and returns authentic noisy energy data to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. As a result, this phase completes with ⊤top\top ensuring 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that the received energy data is not poisoned. End-to-end runtime and memory usage during this operation are shown in Table II.

Next, we launch the following attacks to LDP-DC+:

∙∙\bullet 𝒜​𝖽𝗏1𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏1{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{1} corrupts Init-State to poison the initial state.

∙∙\bullet 𝒜​𝖽𝗏2𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏2{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{2} corrupts LDP-DC between Setup and Collect phases to poison raw energy readings.

∙∙\bullet 𝒜​𝖽𝗏3𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏3{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{3} poisons the state in between Setup and Collect phases.

∙∙\bullet 𝒜​𝖽𝗏4𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏4{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{4} poisons the final result in Collect phase.

LDP-DC+ detects all aforementioned attacks. Specifically, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏1𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏1{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{1} and 𝒜​𝖽𝗏2𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏2{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{2} are detected at the end of Setup and Collect phases, respectively, due to the software binary mismatch. 𝒜​𝖽𝗏3𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏3{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{3} is caught in Collect since 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s RoT noticed tampered state values (from CheckState) and thus refused to generate a valid proof. Similarly, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏4𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏4{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{4} is detected in Collect phase since the proof σ𝜎\sigma does not reflect the tampered output.

IX-F Case Study 2: Federated Learning

Here the service provider aims to train an ML model for identifying anomalous usage patterns in a smart grid system. To achieve this while ensuring user privacy, it employs FL based on a neural network, as described in [27]. Each smart meter independently trains a local neural network model with 8 hidden units on its local data. These local models are later transmitted to and aggregated by the service provider. FL-DC+ is employed to prevent poisoning.

The setup resembles the previous case study, where a smart meter device (𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}) operates on a SAML11 Xplained Pro board. It performs energy readings by interfacing with a PZEM-004T device and connects to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} via serial communication.

During benign operation, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} and 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} initiate FL-DC+ protocol by running Setup phase, which clears all sensor readings on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. Next, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} periodically triggers Collect phase to record an energy reading into a 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-local training dataset. Once 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} records enough energy readings, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} triggers the Train phase by transmitting a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. This request specifies initial weights to be trained on, a learning rate, and the number of epochs to be 100. 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} then performs the local training. Upon completion, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} sends back the updated weights along with the proof of training to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. Since 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} adhere to FL-DC+, the protocol yields ⊤top\top, ensuring to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that the received model was correctly trained on authentic energy data and can thus be safely aggregated onto the global model. Runtime breakdown and memory usage are shown in Table II.

We simulate two types of adversaries: 𝒜​𝖽𝗏D𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏𝐷{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{D} and 𝒜​𝖽𝗏M𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏𝑀{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{M}. 𝒜​𝖽𝗏D𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏𝐷{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{D} performs data poisoning attacks to FL-DC+ by compromising 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-local training dataset before Train is executed. Meanwhile, 𝒜​𝖽𝗏M𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏𝑀{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{M} simulates model poisoning by manipulating the locally trained model parameters before the model arrives at 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}. FL-DC+ detects 𝒜​𝖽𝗏D𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏𝐷{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{D} during the Train phase because 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s RoT identifies state 𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} tampering (𝒮𝒮\sf{\mathcal{S}} is the training dataset in this case). 𝒜​𝖽𝗏M𝒜subscript𝖽𝗏𝑀{\sf{\mathcal{A}dv}}_{M} is caught at the end of the Train as the proof does not match the tampered output.

X Related Work

Poisoning prevention LDP and FL. Aside from data-driven  [57, 23, 6]) and algorithmic [50, 32, 55, 33] poisoning prevention approaches discussed in Section I, a few recent schemes propose system security approaches [11, 48, 2]. To the best of our knowledge, none of these schemes provide 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX}-equivalent guarantee of provable integrity all the way from data acquisition until its de facto usage as an aggregated statistical result or global ML model. They also do not address the issues of input validation or state preservation for arbitrary functions ℱℱ\sf{\mathcal{F}} to be execute on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}.

Verifiable Software Integrity in Embedded Devices. To secure low-end embedded devices, various low-cost security architectures have been proposed for remote verification of their software state via integrity proofs [44]. These proofs vary in terms of expressiveness, with simpler ones confirming correct binary presence (remote attestation) [12, 21, 5, 29, 20, 42], while more expressive ones support verification of arbitrary code execution. Aside from 𝖯𝗈𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖷\sf{PoX} architectures  [13, 8, 45, 34], control flow attestation/auditing (CFA) techniques  [40, 1, 52, 60, 51, 56, 18, 17, 59, 14, 9] prove to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} the exact order in which instructions have executed within a particular code in 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}, thus enabling detection of code reuse attacks that can be triggered if the code whose execution is being proven is itself vulnerable. Data flow attestation [51, 15, 17] augments CFA to generate evidence about memory safety violations even when exploits do not alter a program’s legal control flow path.

Private Data Collection on Edge Devices. Complementary to privacy mechanisms focusing on hiding private data from back-ends (e.g., LDP/FL), recent work has delved into assuring that private data is secure against compromised sensing devices “from its birth”, i.e., from the moment when it is digitized. VERSA [43] was proposed as a HW/SW architecture to guarantee that only the correct execution of expected and explicitly authorized software can access and manipulate sensing interfaces. As a consequence, it blocks malware/modified software from accessing sensitive sensed quantities by default. Following this notion, Sensing And Actuation As A Privilege (SA4P) [16] realizes this concept using ARM TrustZone.

XI Conclusion

We defined and developed stateful proofs of execution, a system security primitive to thwart poisoning in applications such as differential privacy and federated learning. We analyze the security of our design (𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}) and evaluate its performance with an open-source prototype. Results indicate strong poisoning prevention guarantees at modest overhead applicable even to MCU-based resource-constrained IoT devices.
